description: Fiber optic cable installation, testing, and NEC Article 770 requirements

questions.question: What NEC article covers optical fiber cables?
options: Article 770 Optical Fiber Cables and Raceways
questions.explanation: NEC Article 770 covers optical fiber cables and raceways used for communications and signaling.

questions.question: What are the two main types of optical fiber?
questions.explanation: Single-mode (SM) fiber has a small core for long distances; multimode (MM) has larger core for shorter distances.

questions.question: What is the typical core diameter of single-mode fiber?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber has a core diameter of approximately 8-10 microns (typically 9 microns).

questions.question: What is the typical core diameter of OM3/OM4 multimode fiber?
questions.explanation: OM3 and OM4 multimode fibers have 50-micron cores optimized for laser transmission.

questions.question: What color is single-mode fiber jacket typically?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber cables typically have yellow outer jackets per TIA-568 color coding.

questions.question: What color is OM3/OM4 multimode fiber jacket typically?
questions.explanation: OM3 and OM4 laser-optimized multimode fibers have aqua jackets per TIA-568 color coding.

questions.question: What is a fusion splice?
options: Permanent joint created by melting fiber ends together
questions.explanation: Fusion splicing permanently joins fibers by melting the glass ends together using an electric arc.

questions.question: What is OTDR testing?
options: Optical Time Domain Reflectometer - measures loss and locates faults
questions.explanation: OTDR sends light pulses and analyzes reflections to measure fiber length, loss, and locate faults.

questions.question: What is the minimum bend radius for fiber optic cable?
options: Typically 10-15 times cable diameter (varies by cable type)
questions.explanation: Minimum bend radius is typically 10-15 times cable outer diameter; exceeding causes signal loss or breakage.

questions.question: What listing is required for fiber cables in plenums?
questions.explanation: OFNP or OFCP rated cables are required for plenum installations due to fire/smoke requirements.

questions.question: What is the purpose of cladding in optical fiber?
options: Keeps light contained in core through total internal reflection
questions.explanation: Cladding surrounds the core with lower refractive index material, causing total internal reflection to contain light.

questions.question: What tool is used to prepare fiber ends for connectorization?
questions.explanation: A fiber cleaver cuts fiber at a precise angle (typically 90 degrees) for low-loss connections.

questions.question: What is attenuation in fiber optics?
questions.explanation: Attenuation is signal loss in the fiber, measured in decibels per kilometer (dB/km).

questions.question: What type of light source does single-mode fiber typically use?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber uses laser light sources, typically at 1310nm or 1550nm wavelengths.

questions.question: What is a fiber patch panel?
options: Enclosure organizing fiber connections and providing port access
questions.explanation: Patch panels organize fiber terminations and provide accessible ports for connecting equipment.

questions.question: What is the typical fusion splice loss for single-mode fiber?
questions.explanation: Quality fusion splices achieve loss of 0.02-0.05 dB, lower than mechanical splices or connectors.

questions.question: What is connector loss budget for SC connectors?
options: 0.5 dB or less per mated pair
questions.explanation: SC connector pairs typically have 0.5 dB maximum loss per TIA-568 specifications.

questions.question: What does OFNR cable designation mean?
questions.explanation: OFNR is Optical Fiber Nonconductive Riser cable rated for vertical runs between floors.

questions.question: What is the difference between OFN and OFC fiber cables?
options: OFN is nonconductive; OFC is conductive (contains metal)
questions.explanation: OFN cables contain no metallic elements; OFC cables contain conductive elements (metal strength members).

questions.question: What is modal dispersion?
options: Signal spreading in multimode fiber due to different light paths
questions.explanation: Modal dispersion occurs in multimode fiber when different light modes travel at slightly different speeds.

questions.question: What is chromatic dispersion?
options: Signal spreading due to different wavelengths traveling at different speeds
questions.explanation: Chromatic dispersion causes signal spreading because different wavelengths of light travel at different velocities.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a launch cable for OTDR testing?
options: Allows measurement of first connector without dead zone masking
questions.explanation: Launch cables extend beyond the OTDR dead zone so the first connector can be properly measured.

questions.question: What is optical return loss (ORL)?
options: Ratio of reflected light to input light, measured in negative dB
questions.explanation: ORL measures light reflected back toward the source; high ORL (negative dB) indicates good connections.

questions.question: What connector type uses a push-pull latching mechanism?
questions.explanation: LC connectors use a push-pull latch mechanism and are smaller than SC connectors.

questions.question: What is the maximum channel length for OM3 fiber at 10 Gbps?
questions.explanation: OM3 multimode fiber supports 10 Gbps Ethernet up to 300 meters per TIA-568 standards.

questions.question: What is the maximum channel length for OM4 fiber at 10 Gbps?
questions.explanation: OM4 fiber supports 10 Gbps up to 400-550 meters depending on transceiver type.

questions.question: What wavelengths are commonly used for multimode fiber?
questions.explanation: Multimode fiber typically operates at 850nm (LED/VCSEL) and 1300nm wavelengths.

questions.question: What is a mechanical splice?
options: Alignment device that holds fiber ends together without fusing
questions.explanation: Mechanical splices use an alignment mechanism to hold cleaved fiber ends in contact without heat fusion.

questions.question: What is the typical loss for a mechanical splice?
questions.explanation: Mechanical splices typically achieve 0.1-0.3 dB loss, higher than fusion splices but acceptable for many applications.

questions.question: What is the purpose of gel or index matching fluid in mechanical splices?
options: Reduces Fresnel reflections at the fiber junction
questions.explanation: Index matching gel reduces light reflections at the junction by filling the gap with matching refractive index material.

questions.question: What fiber type is specified for new installations per TIA-568?
options: OM3 or OM4 50 micron laser-optimized multimode
questions.explanation: TIA-568 recommends OM3 or OM4 laser-optimized 50-micron fiber for new multimode installations.

questions.question: What is a pigtail in fiber optics?
options: Short fiber with connector on one end for splicing
questions.explanation: A pigtail is a short length of fiber with a factory-terminated connector on one end, spliced to cable fibers.

questions.question: What is breakout cable (fan-out cable)?
options: Cable with individually jacketed fibers for direct connectorization
questions.explanation: Breakout cables have individually jacketed fibers that can be directly terminated with connectors.

questions.question: What is the Insertion Loss Test Method for fiber certification?
options: Measure end-to-end loss using calibrated light source and power meter
questions.explanation: Insertion loss testing measures total link loss using a calibrated light source and optical power meter.

questions.question: What is an OTDR dead zone?
options: Distance after an event where OTDR cannot detect other events
questions.explanation: Dead zones are distances after connectors/splices where the OTDR receiver saturates and cannot detect events.

questions.question: What is WDM (Wavelength Division Multiplexing)?
options: Transmitting multiple signals at different wavelengths on one fiber
questions.explanation: WDM sends multiple signals at different wavelengths simultaneously over a single fiber strand.

questions.question: What is the difference between CWDM and DWDM?
options: CWDM uses wider wavelength spacing; DWDM uses narrower for more channels
questions.explanation: CWDM (Coarse) uses 20nm spacing for up to 18 channels; DWDM (Dense) uses <1nm for 40+ channels.

questions.question: What is PMD (Polarization Mode Dispersion)?
options: Signal distortion from different polarization states traveling at different speeds
questions.explanation: PMD causes pulse spreading due to birefringence making polarization states travel at different velocities.

questions.question: What is the typical attenuation of single-mode fiber at 1310nm?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber has approximately 0.35 dB/km attenuation at 1310nm wavelength.

questions.question: What is the typical attenuation of single-mode fiber at 1550nm?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber has lowest attenuation at 1550nm, approximately 0.20-0.25 dB/km.

questions.question: What causes macrobend loss in fiber?
options: Excessive bending exceeding minimum bend radius causing light leakage
questions.explanation: Macrobend loss occurs when fiber is bent too sharply, allowing light to escape the core.

questions.question: What is an optical amplifier (EDFA)?
options: Erbium-Doped Fiber Amplifier that boosts optical signals directly
questions.explanation: EDFA uses erbium-doped fiber excited by pump laser to amplify optical signals without conversion to electrical.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Tier 1 vs Tier 2 fiber certification?
options: Tier 1 is insertion loss only; Tier 2 adds OTDR characterization
questions.explanation: Tier 1 tests total link loss; Tier 2 adds OTDR testing for detailed characterization of events and loss distribution.

questions.question: What is a VCSEL light source?
options: Vertical Cavity Surface Emitting Laser used for multimode fiber
questions.explanation: VCSEL (Vertical Cavity Surface Emitting Laser) is a low-cost laser source optimized for multimode fiber.

questions.question: What documentation is required for fiber optic system installation?
options: Test results, splice records, cable routes, and as-built drawings
questions.explanation: Complete documentation including test results, splice maps, cable routes, and as-built drawings is essential.
